conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C, we need to analyze the changes in the internal energy (U) and pressure (p) of the gas during this process.
The internal energy U of the ideal gas is related to the temperature T by the equation \(U = aT\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.
Express the internal energy at state B as \(U_{B} = aT_{B}\).
The internal energy is also related to the pressure and volume by the equation \(U = pV\).
Express the internal energy at state C as \(U_{C} = p_{C}V_{C}\).
Substitute the volume at state C, \(0.5V_{0}\), into the equation for \(U_{C}\): \(U_{C} = p_{C} \times 0.5V_{0}\).
Express the internal energy at state C as \(U_{C} = aT_{B} \times 0.5V_{0}\).
Calculate the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C: \(W = U_{C} - U_{B}\).
Substitute the expressions for \(U_{C}\) and \(U_{B}\) into the equation for work: \(W = (aT_{B} \times 0.5V_{0}) - (aT_{B})\).
Simplify the expression for work: \(W = 0.5aT_{B}V_{0} - aT_{B}\).
Since \(a\) is a positive constant, the negative sign indicates that the work done by the gas is an increase in the internal energy of the gas.
Therefore, the work done by the gas when it changes from state B to state C is: \(W = 0.5aT_{B}V_{0}\).
